bibl.title: Plains Cree Texts
bibl.series: Publications of the American Ethnological Society, Volume XVI

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: pêyak êsah nâpêw kaspwân isiyîhkâsôw . A certain man, the story goes, was called Gaspard.
itôwahk nawâc pikoh kâ-môhcôwicik , kisâstâw êkotôwah ês âwah awa nâpêw . Of the kind that are more crazy than anything else, of that kind, to all appearance, was that man.
êkwah mistahi kitimâkêyimik ostêsah . His elder brother was fond of him and cared for him.
êkwah kîtahtawê âhkosiyiwa . Then at one time the elder brother took sick.
êkwah wiya kaspwân nama wîhkâc êsah atoskêw . But as for Gaspard, he never worked.
êkwah pikoh awâsisah nayêstaw piko êh-mêtawâkêt , êko piko nayêstaw êy-isi-atoskêt . He only played with the children, that was the only kind of work he did.
nama kêkway kotak êyako piko êh-âtoskâtahk , awâsisah pikoh êh-otaminât . At nothing else he worked, only at amusing the children.
nîsiyiwa ostêsah ocawâsimisiyiwa . His brother had two children.
kîtahtawê ostêsah ôki mac-âyîsiyiniwak êh-mihcêticik nipahêwak êyakonih anihih . Presently those evil men, who were many, killed that elder brother of his.
êkwah wiya piko kaspwân k-êsiyîhkâsot êkwah mistahi êh-kîhtimit . Then there was left only that Gaspard, who was so lazy.
kêyiwêhk pamihêw awa iskwêw wîtimwa ; mistahi kitimâkêyimêw . That woman took such care as she was able of her brother-in-law; she treated him with most pitying kindness.
êkwah piko awâsisah nayêstaw êh-otaminât . And all he did, even now, was to amuse the children.
mistahi mâna pakwâtam awa iskwêw , êkâh wîhkâc êh-atoskêyit ôhi wîtimwa . The woman was very much dissatisfied because her brother-in-law never worked.

ahpôh nama wîhkâc nikohtêw awa kaspwân , osâm mistahi êh-kîhtimit , êkwah piko wîtimwa êh-atoskêyit . That Gaspard never even gathered firewood, for he was too lazy; his sister-in-law did all the work.
êtataw nawac pikoh êsah asamisôwak . They had barely enough to eat.

kîtahtawê ômisi itêyihtam , ê-wih-mâcîwiht :
mahtih nika-wîcihiwân ! itêyihtam êsah awa iskwêw ; Presently, when the people were about to go on a hunt, she thought, “I had better go along!” thought the woman;
mâskôc wîh-wêpihihcih nîtim , itêyihtam êsah . “Perhaps my brother-in-law will be aroused to some activity,” she thought.
tâpwê êkos îsi isi-wîcêwêw . So accordingly she took him along.
êkwah nama kêkway âhci pikoh awa kaspwân , piyisk âta ê-wâh-wanihikêwiht . But Gaspard still did nothing at all, even though the people were trapping.
piyisk êkos îsi isi-piciwân . Finally their band moved camp.
ntawac namoya awa iskwêw wîh-piciw . The woman needs determined not to move.
ayisk namoya wîtimwah wîh-atoskêyiwa . For her brother-in-law would not do any work.
êkwah awa iskwêw wâkayôsah miskawêw . Then the woman found a bear.
nipahêw êsah . She killed it.
mistah êh-wiyinowit , êkotah ohci mistahi mâwacihtâw pimiy . As the beast was very fat, she took a great amount of grease from it.
êkwah wâposwah êh-nâ-nipahât , piyisk mistahi mîsihtâw . And since she also kept killing rabbits, finally she had a big store of food.
êkwah kîtahtawê kîkisêpâh namwâc wîh-mîcisôw awa kaspwân . Then at one time Gaspard would not eat anything in the morning.
mâmaskâtam awa wîtimwa êkâ êh-wîh-mîcisoyit awa iskwêw . The woman was surprised that her brother-in-law would not eat.
tânêhk oma êkâ o-wîh-mîcisot ? itêyihtam êsah . “Why does he not want to eat?” she thought.
âsay mîna namoya mîcisôw êh-âpihtâ-kîsikâyik . At noon again he did not eat.
piyisk êh-tipiskâyik namoya mîcisôw . Then, in the evening, he did not eat.
êh-wâpaniyik mîna êh-asamât , namoya wîh-mîcisôyiwa . In the morning, when again she gave him food, he would not eat.
piyisk mîna tipiskâyiw , êkâ ê-wîh-mîcisot . Night came, and still he would not eat.
tânêhk ôma ? itwêw awa oskinîkiskwêw . “What is the matter?” said the young woman.

êkwah ,
nîtim , êkâya nântaw itêyihtah . Then, “Sister-in-Law, do not worry about it.
namoya êh-âhkosiyân , itwêw êsa awa kaspwân . It is not that I am ill,” said Gaspard.

kêhcinâh , itêyihtam aw îskwêw ,
êh-akâwâsit , itêyimêw ôhi wîtimwah . “Surely,” thought the woman, “he must be falling in love with me,” she thought of her brother-in-law.

êkwah kîtahtawê ômis îtwêw :
nîtim , kâya êkosi itêyimin . Then presently he spoke thus: “Sister-in-Law, do not think that of me.
kontah êkosi kitêyihtên , itwêw êsah . You are mistaken in thinking that,” he said.
êkwa kîtahtawê nêyo-kîsikâw namoya êsah mîcisôw . Then presently, for four days he had not eaten.

ôtah ômis êsah itwêw :
nîtim , itwêw êsah ,
an ôskinîkiskwêw ôtah kâ-kîh-ayât wîhtikôwiw . Then he spoke as follows: “Sister-in-Law,” he said, “that young woman who was here has become a Windigo.
pikoh kita-kakwêyâhoyin ta-tapasiyahk , itwêw êsah ; The only thing for you to do is to hurry preparations that we may flee,” he said;
anohc kâ-tipiskâk kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwah êkotê k-âyâyit ta-mêscihêw , itwêw êsah ; “This very night she will kill all the people who are staying over there,” he said;
wâpahkih tipiskâki ôtah ta-takohtêw , itwêw êsah ; “Tomorrow night she will arrive here,” he said;
tapasîtân kiyâm , itwêw êsah awa nâpêw . “Let us flee, do,” said that man.
tâpwê êh-wâpaniyik mayaw mâci-wawêyîwak . Then in the morning, at once they began to make ready.

seg.q: têpiyâhk kicawâsimisak itah ta-pôsihacik pêyak pikoh otâpânâsk sipwêhtah .
seg.gloss: “Take along at any rate one sled, so that you can at least let your children ride.”

p.seg: tâpwê nêo atimwa êsa wiyahpitêw . Accordingly she harnessed four dogs.
êkwah ôhi wêwêkinêw ôtâpânâskwah , têpiyâhk êkos îsi êy-isi-tapasîcik . She covered the sled, and with nothing more they went.

âsay êkwah mâmaskâtêw awa iskwêw wîtimwa pêyahtik ê-pa-pimohtêyit ; êkwah wiya mitoni sîhkimik sôhki kitah-pakamahwât atimwa . It was not long before the woman was wondering at the way her brother-in-law slowly walked along; for at the same time he was urging her to beat the dogs to a good pace.
tâpwê tapasîw . So she fled.
êkâya manâtaskasin , itwêw awa kaspwân . “Do not worry about leaving me behind,” said Gaspard.
tâpwê sôhki tapasîw awa iskwêw , âhci piko kâ-pa-pmohtêyit ôhi wîtimwa . Really, the woman fled with speed, while her brother-in-law merely strolled along.
mâmaskâtam , âhci piko êh-pa-pmohtêyit pêyahtik . She wondered at the quiet way he ambled on.

êkwah itêw ,
kisiwâk êkwah pê-ayâw . Then he told her, “Now she has come near.
kahkiyaw êkwah anihi kâ-kih-piciyit kitamwêw , itwêw awa nâpêw . She is eating up all those who moved camp,” said that man.
mistahi pakwâtam aw îskwêw . The woman was greatly distressed.
êcik âwa êh-manitôwit ! itêyimêw êsa wîtimwa ; “So it seems that he has manitou power!” she thought of her brother-in-law;
êwakoh êcik âwa êkâ k-ôh-wih-atoskêt ! itêyihtam êsa awa iskwêw . “So that is why he will never do any work!” thought the woman.
êkwah atih-tipiskâyiw . Darkness was falling.
êh-ati-tipiskâyik , âhci piko pimâmôwak . When it grew dark, they nevertheless went fleeing on.
nîtim , êkwah kîkinaw pêw-otihtam , itwêw êsah . “Sister-in-Law, now she has reached our dwelling,” he said.
êkwah tâpwê tapasîwak . Then truly they fled.
êkwah tâpwê mîcisôw aw îskwêw . So then the woman ate.
mayaw êh-kîsi-mîcisocik , atimwa ê-kîh-asamât , tapasîwak . As soon as they had eaten, after feeding the dogs, they went on in flight.
êkwah tâpwê êh-atih-wâpaniyik , misi-sâkahikan otihtamwak . Then, as dawn came, they reached a large lake.
wêpinik atimwak , itêw wîtimwa . “Turn the dogs loose,” he told his sister-in-law.
tâpwê aw îskwêw wêpinêw atimwah . So the woman turned the dogs loose.
êkwah wîtimwah nayômêw êkwah ocawâsimisah . Then he took his sister-in-law and the children on his back.

pêyak awa iskwêw nayômêw ; êkwah awa nâpêw tahkonêw wîtimwa mîna nayêw . The woman took one on her back; the man took hold of his sister-in-law, and bore her on his back. LB on {nayêw}: The last word is almost certainly an error; probably read {nayômêw}: “he carried her on his back”; the sentence is somewhat tangled.
êkwah tapasîw . Then he fled.
atimwah wêpinêwak . They turned loose the dogs.
êkwa kâ-pêtsâpamâcik miskwamihk êh-pê-pmohtêyit ôhi iskwêwa . And then they saw that woman come walking toward them over the ice.

kîtahtawê ,
sôhkih tapasîh , nîtim . Then, soon, “Flee with all your might, Brother-in-Law.
âsay kikitimâkêyimin ! itwêw aw îskwêw . You have taken pity on me!” said the woman.
kîtahtawê wâskahikanah atâwêkamik it êh-ayâyik otihtamwak . Presently they came to some wooden houses of a trading post.

ômis îtwêwak :
awa iskwêw wîhtikôw nipê-mâkohikonân ! itwêw êsah ; They spoke thus: “We have been driven here by that Windigo woman!” she said;
mistahi nîtim manitôwiw , itwêw êsah ; “My brother-in-law has great manitou power,” she said;
kiyâm sîhkimihk ; mâskôc ahpôh kita-nipahêw wîhtikôwa , itwêw êsah . “Do ask him; perhaps he will even kill the Windigo,” she said.
tâpwê otatâwêw wiya tipiyaw itohtêw . Then the trader came in person.

ômis îtêw anahi nâpêwa :
kitimâkêyiminân , kaspwân ! He said to that man, “Take pity on us, Gaspard!

seg.gloss: The Windigo will destroy us all.

seg.q: iyikohk âpihtaw ôtah kêkway êy-astêk ka-miyitin .
seg.gloss: Half of the goods that are here I will give you.”

seg.q: âta wiya êkoyikohk kêkway mistah ôtah astêw atâwêkamikohk .
seg.gloss: “Then all the goods, as many as are here in the trading post.”

p.seg:
êhag , itwêw awa kaspwân ,
mâka iskwêw-ayôwinisah nîswâyih osîhtâk , itwêw êsah ; “Very well,” said Gaspard, “but make two suits of women's clothes,” he said;
kakwêyâhok , itwêw êsah . “Hurry up,” he said.
tâpwê kakwêyâhowak nîswâyih iskwêw-ayôwinisah êy-osîhtâcik . So they hastened to make two suits of women's clothes.
tâpwê êkosi isi wawêyîw . So he dressed himself.
kîkway mîna ? itik ôhi atâwêwah . “What else?” the trader asked him.

nîso mîna akwanânak nintawêyimâwak , itêw êsah ,
nîso mina tâpiskâkanak , êkwah cîkahikanis . “I need also two shawls,” he told him, “and two necklaces, and a hatchet.”
tâpwê kahkiyaw miyâwak . They were given everything.
êkwah ê-kîh-miyihcik , âhci piko natomêw sênapânah . When the things had been given to them, he called for ribbons beside.
êkwah postayôwinisêwak . Then they put on the clothes.
êkwah itohtêwak . Then they went there.
pêy-askôwin , nîtim , itêw êsah . “Follow close behind me, Sister-in-Law,” he told her.
tâpwê pêy-askôwêw awa wîtimwa iskwêw . So the woman followed close behind her brother-in-law.

mayaw êh-otihtâcik , samaskipayihôw maskwamîhk awa oskinîkiskwêw kâ-kîh-wîhtikôwit . As soon as they came to where she was, that young woman who had turned into a windigo throw herself flat on the ice.
kâsôw ; kâtâw ôhkwâkan . She hid herself; she hid her face.

kipê-ntomitin , nicâhkos ! itêw êsah awa kâ-ntawi-nipahât . “I have come to invite you, my gossip,” he who had come to kill her said to her. LB on {nicâhkos}: he addresses her as “my sister-in-law”, with a word used by woman to woman. He throws off the disguise a few lines below, when he addressed his real sister-in-law as {nîtim}, a word used only between persons of opposite sex.
namwâc êsah wîh-kitotik ahpôh . She would not even speak to him.
namwâc ahpôh wîh-kitâpamik . She would not so much as look at him.
mistah ôma namoya kwayask kitôtên , mihcêt ayîsiyiniwak êh-kitamwacik ! itwêw êsah . You do very wrong to eat up many people!” he said.
êkwah pasikôw awa oskinîkiskwêw . Then that young woman rose to her feet.
namoya mâka misawâc ka-kî-sâkôcihin ! itwêw êsah . “Nevertheless, You will not be able to overcome me!” she said.

sêmâk êh-atih-têpwêt , ômis îtêw awa wîtimwah :
nîtim , kiyâm kiya pakamah !
At once he called out and said to his sister-in-law, “Sister-in-Law, please, do you strike her down!
osâm nimacêyimâw ! itwêw êsah . I think her of too little account!” he said.
tâpwêh awa iskwêw pakamahwêw êsah ôhi wîhtikôwa . Accordingly the woman struck down that Windigo.
êkosi nipahêwak . So they killed her.

êkwah ômis îtêw :
nîtim , kwayask âcimôhkan êy-isi-nipahâyâhk . Then he told her, “Sister-in-Law, do you then tell aright the tale of how we killed her.”
êkosi êkwah aw ôskinîkiw kâ-kihtimit , êkosi êkwah miyâc-âtoskêt . And after that this youth, who had been so lazy, began to work.
ê-kîh-nipahât , mâci-nikohtêw . When he had killed that person, he began to gather fire-wood.
mayaw kîkisêpâ kisi-piminawasôw . Early in the morning he had his cooking done.
mâmaskâtam aw îskwêw , êkwah êh-mâc-âtoskêyit ; ôkihtimiyih ! The woman wondered at his now beginning to work; he had been so lazy!
êkwa mîna êkosi mina mâcîw awa . And then, too, he began to hunt.
nama wîhkâc êkwah apiw . Now he never sat at home.
kiyâm niya nik-ônâpêmin ! itêyihtam êsah aw îskwêw . “Let me be the one to have him for my husband!” thought that woman.
akâwâtêw wîtimwa . She fell in love with her brother-in-law.
matwân_sîh nika-pakwâtik ? itêyihtam êsah . “Can it be that he will reject me?” she thought.

kîtahtawê êh-apiyit ,
nîtim , kitimâkêyimin . Then, at one time, when he was at home, “Brother-in-Law, take pity on me.
kiyâm niya wîkimin ; êkâ wiya pîtos awiyak wîkim , itwêw êsah aw îskwêw . Do marry me; do not marry anyone else,” said that woman.

seg.q: tâpwê , nîtim , âtah êsa kwayask kititwah .
seg.gloss: “Truly, Sister-in-Law, you have spoken like a good woman.

p.seg: namoya cêskwa ta-kîh-wîwiyân , itêw êsah wîtimwa ; But I cannot yet a while take a wife,” he told his sister-in-law,
kîspin wîwiyâni , wîpac nika-nipin , itwêw êsah awa nâpêw kaspwân . “If I take a wife, I shall soon die,” said that man, Gaspard.
êkwah âsay mîna kîhtwâm kakwêcimêw wîtimwa . Then again she questioned her brother-in-law.
tâpwê kikitimahin , nîtim , êkâ wîkimiyin , itwêw êsah aw îskwêw ; “Truly, you cause me sorrow, Brother-in-Law, by not marrying me,” said that woman;

tâpw êtokê êh-kitimâkêyimât ôhi otawâsimisah ? kitêyimitih ! itêw êsah wîtimwah . “'I wonder if he really loves the children!' I have been thinking of you!” she said to her brother-in-law. LB on {otawâsimisah}: Literally, “his children”, instead of “his brother's children”; so usually of straight nephews and nieces, rather than the specific terms, {nikosim} and {nicôsim}.
êhag , nîtim , nikitimâkêyimâwak ; êwak ôhci k-ôh-pamihtwâtân , itêw êsah . “Indeed, Sister-in-Law, I love them; that is why I am supporting them for you,” he told her.
êhag , nîtim , têpiyâhk aciyaw wîkimitâni ! itwêw êsah . “Oh, Brother-in-Law, if I could be married to you for even a little time!” she said.
tâpwê wîwiw ncawâc wîtimwa . So he needs took his sister-in-law to wife.
êh-mâci-piciwiht , atih-sêmâk-wîcihiwêwak . When the people began to move camp, they went along at once.

mistahi nihtâh-minâhôw ; mîna ê-nihtâh-wanîhikêt , mitoni nanâtohk atâwâkanah misiwê nâh-nipahêw . he was very good at killing game; and he was a good trapper, too, and continued to kill many furred things of all kinds.
ohtêyimâw . He was envied.
mac-âyîsiyiniwak oyasowâtêwak êsah , ê-wîh-kakwê-nipahâcik . Some evil men decided to try to kill him.
îkatêpiciwak êsa . They moved camp away from the trail.
osâm mistahi nikitimahikonân kaspwân , ntaw-îtwêwak wîkiwâyihk . “Gaspard is making us too poor,” they said in their lodge to which they had gone.

takohtêw awa kaspwân , kahkiyaw êsah kâh-piciwiht ,
tânêhki k-ôh-picicik ? êh-itwêt . Gaspard came and saw that all his band had moved camp and asked, “Why have they moved camp?”
wîhtamowâw mistahi êh-kisiwahât . He was told that he had greatly angered them.
tâpwê nêw ôki mistah êh-manitôwicik kisiwâsiwak . And really, four who had great manitou power were angry.

itwêwak ,
ohcitaw kika-nipahânaw ! itwêwak ; They said, “By all means, let us kill him!
namoya ka-kîh-pwâtawihânaw ! itwêwak mac-âyîsiyiniwak . Not by any chance can we fail of him!” said the evil men.
nêwak êsah , mistah êh-manitôwicik . They were four, who had great manitou power.

tâpwê mâcih-osîhtâwak êsah , ê-wîh-kosâpahtahkik , ê-wih-kakwê-nipahâcik . And so they set about building that which they would use for the medium's work, meaning to try to kill him. LB on {ê-wîh-kosâpahtahkik}: This is the Ojibwa {tcîsâhkân}, Menomini {tsî?sâhkyan}, cf. Skinner, _Anthropological Papers of the American Museum of Natural History_, XIII, 192.
tâpwê âtah êh-pê-ntomiht , opawâkaniyiwa êh-ntomikot , namoya tâpwêhtam . Truly, though he was summoned from his home, though their dream spirit summoned him, he gave no heed.
nêwo-tipiskâw tahto-tipiskâw ê-kosâpahtahkik ôki mac-âyîsiyiniwak , namoya kîh-itohtêyiwa . For four nights every night those evil men used the medium's tent, but he did not go there.
tâpwê nôtokêw awa ntonawêw êsah , ê-misikitiyit otihkomah mayaw êh-miskawât . So the old woman looked for one, and straightway found a large one of her lice.
ocihcihk êsa ahêw awa nâpêw . The man set it on his hand.
tâpwê mayaw êkwah êh-pê-ntomikot ôhi pawâtâkanah , itohtêw . Then, as soon as those dream spirits came and summoned him, he went there.
pîhtokêw kosâpahcikanihk . He went into the medium's tent.
êkwah tâpwê mawinêhok ôhi . Then truly they sought fight with him.

ômis êsah itêw :
kikitimâkisinâwâw kâ-wî-kakwê-nipahiyêk , itwêw êsah ; Thus he spoke to them: “You are pitiable, you who mean to kill me,” he said;
namoya kkîh-nipahinâwâw , itwêw êsah ; “You cannot kill me,” he said;
mistahi nimanitôwin , itwêw êsah . “I have great manitou power,” he said.
hâw , pakitinêw ihkwah . There, he set down the louse.
kita-wih-nipahik awa mac-âyîsiyiniw ôhi ihkwah ! itwêw êsah . “Let this evil man be killed by this louse!” he said.
tâpwê mac-âyîsiyiniw êsah nipahik ôhi ihkwah . Then truly, the evil man was killed by the louse.
kipwatâmoskâk . It stopped up his breath.
misiwê otônihk pîhtokêyiwa ; êkos îsi nipahik , êh-kipwatâmoskâkot ihkwah . It went into his mouth and down his throat; and so the louse killed him by stopping his windpipe.

tânis êkwah kâ-manitôwit ? itwêwak êsah ;
tânisi ? “Why, what is the matter with the manitou man?” they asked; “What is it?”
kipatâmoskâk ihkwah ! itwêwak êsah . “A louse choked him!” they said.
namwâc êsah kîh-nahinâw , êkos êy-isi-wêpiniht , osâm mistahih ihkwak êh-ayâcik . It was not even possible to bury him, and he was merely left there, for there were too many lice.
âsay mîna kîhtwâm êh-tipiskâk kotak awa mac-âyîsiyiniw , êwakoh wîh-kakwê-nipahêw . When the next night came, the second evil man tried to kill him.
âsay mîna êwako sîhkihkêmôw , kosâpahcikan t-ôsihtâwiht . This one, too, gave instructions that they build a medium's lodge for him.
tâpwê osîhtâwân kosâpahcikan . So a medium's tent was built for him.
mayaw êh-kîsihtâwiht , âsay mîna pê-natomâw . As soon as they had finished it for him, again he was summoned.
âsay mîna ôhkomah ntotamowêw , kotakah ta-miyikot ihkwah . Again he asked his grandmother to give him a louse.
tâpwê awa nôtokêsiw minah kotakah ntonawêw otihkomah . So the old woman looked for another of her lice.
âsay mîna êwakoni ntaw-ohcih-nipahêw . He went and killed this one, too, with it.
mac-âyîsiyiniwah kahkiyaw mêscihêw . He killed off all the evil men.

nêo-tipiskâw tahto-tipiskâw êw-osîhtâyit êsah kosâpahcikan , kahkiyaw êsah anikih mac-âyîsiyiniwak ihkway êsah kîh-mêscih-nipahikwak , nêo mac-âyîsiyiniwak . Having for four nights every night set up a medium's tent, all those evil men were killed off by lice, four evil men.
êkwah ntawi-mawimostawêwak ôhi kaspwâna . Then they went to entreat Gaspard.
kiyâm kitimâkêyimanân ! kiyâm êkâya niyanân nipahinân ! itwêw êsah . “Pray, take pity on us! Pray, do not kill us, too!” the spokesman said.
tâpwê namoya kiyawâw kâ-kisiwâhiyêk , itwêw êsah kaspwân ; “Really, it is not you who made me angry,” said Gaspard;
ayâwihkok ôki kâ-wîh-miyiyêk , itwêw êsah . “Keep those things you mean to give me,” he said.
kîtahtawê mîna kotakak ôki mac-âyîsiyiniwak mastaw êhtakocik . Presently, there came into being, later, some more evil men.
ayisk wiya êkwah okimâwiw awa kaspwân . Now, by this time, this Gaspard was the chief.
pê-ntomâw êh-mâmawôpicik ôki ayîsiyiniwak , êkotah ohci pê-ntomâw . They sent for him. From where those people were sitting in assembly, he was sent for.
wîhtikôw kiwîh-otihtikonaw , itwêwak ôki nâpêwak . “A Windigo is coming to where we are,” said those men.
êwak ôm ohci k-ôh-mâmawopicik , êkwah êh-pê-ntomiht awa kaspwân . That was why they were sitting in council, and why Gaspard was sent for.

seg.gloss: When New Year's Day has passed again, then he will arrive.
Let them think no more about it.”

p.seg: êkosi tâpwê namoya takohtêw wîhtikôw . And really, the Windigo did not come.
piyisk êkosi namoya na-nâkatôhkêwak . In time they ceased from their alertness.
piyis mîna niyîpihk êkwah êh-ati-takwâkihk , mâci-wawêyîwak omâcîwak . Then, when summer had passed and autumn was coming on, the hunters began to make ready.
nka-wîcêwâwak , itwêw êsah kaspwân ; “I shall go with them,” said Gaspard;
anohc oma kâ-pipohk , êkwah kâ-wîh-takohtêt wîhtikôw , itwêw êsah ; “This winter is when the Windigo will come,” he said;

seg.gloss: “To be sure, I am not certain that I shall be able to kill him.

p.seg: nawac pikoh nikostâw , itwêw êsah kaspwâl . Rather, in fact, I fear him,” said Gaspard. LB on {kaspwâl}: Plainly so pronounced: {l} exists in neighboring dialects, while {r} is quite impossible. But I cannot accout for the {w} in the Cree form.
tâpwê êsa wawêyîw wîstah . And so he too got ready.
pimitisahikêw êsah . He followed the others about.

kâ-mâci-piciwiht , êkotê êh-ay-ayâcik , tahto-tipiskâw ayîsiyiniwak ôki kostâcîskâkwak wîhtikôwa , tahkih êsah êh-mâmawopicik . When the band started to move, then off in that place where they were, every night those people were frightened for the coming of the Windigo, and would always sit assembled.
mwêhci êh-apihtâ-piponiyik , êh-âti-tipiskâyik , wîsâmêw wîwa . Exactly in the middle of winter, one night, as darkness came on, he asked his wife to go with him.

ômisih êsah itêw :
anohc êkwah kâ-wîh-tipiskâk wîhtikôw kâ-wîh-takosihk . He said to her, “In this very night that is now at hand, is when the Windigo will arrive.
kîstânaw ntawâpahtân , itêw êsah wîwah . Let us too be on the lookout,” he told his wife. CHECK ntawâpahtân. HCW: probably best
tâpwê wawêyîw awa iskwêw . So the woman dressed up.
itohtêwak , wiyawa mîna êh-ntawâpicik . They went there, that they too might watch.
mayaw êh-pîhtokêcik mistahi miywêyihtamwân . As soon as they entered the tipi, all the people were very glad.

ômis îtêw ôhi nâpêwah :
âhkamêyimok ! He said to those men, “Do your best!
anohc êkwah , kêkâc wâpahkih , wîhtikôw wîh-takosin , itwêw êsah . Tonight, just before dawn, the Windigo will arrive,” he said.
sâsay êkwah pêhtamwak ayîsiyiniwak mosis wîhtikôwa êh-matwê-yêhyêyit . By this time the people heard plainly the loud breathing of the Windigo.

êkwah ômis îtwêw :
acosisah osîhtâk mitoni êh-apisâsikih . Then he said, “Make some very small arrows.”
êh-kîsihtâwiht , miyâw . When they had been finished for him, he was given them.
tâpwê kêtayôwinisêw ; osâwasiskîwastênisôw . Then he took off his clothes; he painted himself with ochre.
êkwah nahapiw . Then he sat down.
êkotah êsah sêmâk kwêskimôw , êsah êh-âpisc-awâsisiwit . Then, all at once, he changed his form, turning into a little child.

mitonih mâmaskâtamwak êsah ôki nâpêwak êkotah k-âyâcik , apisc-awâsisah êh-wâpamâcik , ê-kwêskimowit kaspwân . Those men who were there were greatly amazed when they saw the little child into which Gaspard had transformed himself.
êkos îsi ati-isi-ohpiskâw , êh-ntawi-nakiskawât wîhtikôwa . Thereupon, in that form, he rose into the air, to go and encounter the Windigo.
mistah êsah kinosiyiwa ôhi wîhtikôwa , kahkiyaw êsah mistikwa êh-ayiwâkiskawâyit , êyikohk êh-kinosiyit . That Windigo was very tall, so tall that he overtopped all the trees.
tâpwê nakiskawêw ; êh-atimapiyit êsah otihtêw . Really, he met him; he came upon him as he sat facing yon way.
kîkway ôtah êw-osîhtâyin ? itêw êsah ; “What are you doing here?” he asked him;

seg.gloss: “What is it you mean to do?”

p.seg: anohc kâ-tipiskâk kahkiyaw kiwîh-kitamôtinâwâw ! itik êsah . “Tonight I mean to devour you all!” the other told him.
mâcih-têpwêwak , êh-nôtinitocik , mistikwa minah êkwah ê-pâh-pahkwacipitâcik , êh-ohci-pâh-pakamahotocik . They began to whoop, as they fought, tearing up trees with which they beat each other.
nipahêw êsa . He killed him.
êkosi mistahi ohtêyihtamwak oskinîkiwak . Then the young men were very envious.

seg.gloss: “How do you suppose we shall be able to kill him?

p.seg: ômisi kakwêh-isi-nipahâtân , itwêwak êsah ôki oskinîkiwak ; Let us try to kill him in this way,” said those young men;

mahtih wâh-wîhtamâtotân kêkway kit-si-ki-ohci-nipahikawiyahk , kik-êtânâw , itwêwak êsah oskinîkiwak . “'Let us tell one another by what means each of us can be killed,' we will say to him,” said the young men. CHECK kiy-si...
tâpwê tahto-tipiskâw mâna êh-mâh-mâmawopicik , tahtoh ôki kâ-pawâmicik wâh-wîhtamâtôwak . Accordingly, every night, as they sat assembled in their usual way, they told one another their dreams.
kîtahtawê êsah wîstah k-êtohtêt . Then at one time he too went there.
namoya kontah ta-kih-pîhtokêyin , itik ôhi oskinîkiwah ; “You cannot come in without paying the price,” the young men said to him;
tântôwihk kiya êkâ k-ô-kî-nipahikawiyin ? itik êsa . “To what manner of thing is it due that you cannot be killed?” they asked him.
nama wîhkâc nika-nipahikawin , itwêw êsah ; “I shall never be killed,” he said;

seg.q: pêyak kêkway sîpâ misitihk kêkway kit-ôhtinamihk kita-mâhtakoskâkoyân .
seg.gloss: “There is but one thing: if something taken from under one's foot surmounted me.”

p.seg: mayaw êh-tipiskâyik , ntaw-astâwân sîpâ itôwahk kâ-tahkoskâtamihk mâna asâmihk ohci . As soon as night had come, they went and placed on him the kind of thing that is stepped on underneath, from a snowshoe.
êkosi êsah kî-nâspici-nipâw . Thereupon he never awoke from his sleep.
êkotah êsah kîh-nipahâw kaspwân , osâm mistahi êh-kîh-manitôwakêyimot . So at this point Gaspard was killed, because he had thought himself too much of a manitou.
tahkohc otakohpihk êh-astâwiht anima , kâ-nipahikot asâmêyâpiy . When that thing was placed on top of his blanket, he was killed by the snowshoe strap.
êkoyikohk êh-mêscîhtâyân , êh-kîsihtâyân . Now I have told it all, now I have finished it.
